content.description:
Start on obvious, flat underclings, and move up and right following a seam into the topout as for

Last Resort

.
content.location: It is on the Drunken Master Boulder.

content.description: This is a really cool line of slopers and crimps on a huge boulder.  Start matched on the lowest big sloper (might help to stack some pads), and go up and right to top it out.  There is also a line that branches to the left, but I think it's harder.
content.protection: Two pads is really all you need, but it helps to have a few more just to get on the thing.
content.location:
Go around the left hand side of the

Double Clutch

Boulder, and scramble uphill a bit between some boulders.  Pretty soon it will clear and you can look to the right to see this problem, which is just left of an offwidth dihedral crack.  The obvious dihedral problem, the Vice, is a bit more to the right.

content.description: Start on a right hand sidepull/pinch with a thumbcatch, left hand on obvious rail.  The crux is making the cross to the the crack.  There are a few different ways to do the topout from heelhook to dyno.  It is a great problem.
content.location:
Last Resort is at the end of the long wall, the opposite end from La Crimp and

Clutch

.

content.description:
This route was installed thanks to the Arthur's Rock Fixed Anchor Initiative (2013).

Please consult the Lory State Park Rock Climbing guide for more information:

nococlimbing.org/guidebooks…

Climb the obvious arête just to the right of

Drunken Master

. A technical traverse leads to the first bolt, then continue up the arête on knobs and edges with a final crux before the chains. The 3rd bolt can be tricky to clip your first time, but this routes anchor is easily accessed for top rope inspection.
content.location: This route is located on the Drunken Master Boulder in the Main Bouldering Area of Arthurs Rock, Lory State Park.

content.description: This is the only line less than V4 in the nearby vicinity.  Fingerlock with the right hand, pounce to the next rail, and throw over the lip.
content.location:
It is just left of

Ode to Failure

.

content.description: This is a great slab problem that is not to be taken lightly. This problem could really be considered a short solo and falling anywhere can make for a really bad day. That said, if you can keep your head right, this is a very fun mental testpiece with great movement on high quality rock. Bring your chalk, watch for the small crux about 2/3 up, and have fun!
content.protection: 20 pads or no pads, either way the recommendation is not to fall, if for nothing other than the cheese grater factor.
content.location: It is located in the "main area." Walk up the bouldering access trail and head downhill on the faint trail when you see the huge arete on one of the largest boulders in the park just before the warm-up boulder.

content.description: Jumpstart to the amazing pinch feature, and move up and right to a sloping gaston. The crux is moving back left to a horrible gaston and a bad edge at the lip. This has seen very few ascents.
content.location: It is on the Drunken Master Boulder.

content.description:
This is the obvious sit start to

Ode to Failure

. Start with a small left hand edge and a good hold on the arête. Climb nice compression moves to the finish of

Ode to Failure

.
content.location: It is on the Ode to Failure Boulder.
